title: Deploying Cloud Solution – T-HT real life experience
segmentation: Coming back to this one presentation, he actually raised a very interesting topic topic and this is.
How localized companies can basically survive in Cloudera?
Or how can even local telecoms surviving Cloudera if Amazon or Rackspace is so much bigger, so much better?
Has such a better economies of scale and basically such a better pricing?
But and this is the question, actually that you get.
Always when we start speaking to some telecom or some company about cloud solutions here.
In the region.
An at the end, as spent also mentioned, there is no concrete data.
There is no feasibility study that there is no marketing study.
There is no sales data.
Then you can count on and say yes.
This is it.
I need my cloud.
It will make me a profitable company and I will earn money in two years.
There is no such thing.
Basically at the end people are thinking I have to go this way.
Otherwise I may run out of my business.
And just be a bit by provider which actually happened couple of times so far in history.
Coming with with Apple App Store with Google and some other companies that local telecoms just found the self providing more and more bandwidth for less and less money.
So the question was OK, let's not do the same thing once again.
But
In the end you have to do something so you just cannot say yes.
I will do that and I will do basically.
Something an OK. Let's now talk about something.
Yeah I would like an Amazon service.
Great, but that costs few thousands, few 10s of millions of euros and basically this region is not Biggs as something that Amazon can deploy.
So first of all, yes we need to deploy it a bit smaller.
Yes, we need to deploy something that will be more similar to Amazon Services or let's say competitive to some.
Do some sort to Amazon services because at the end Amazon is global, so it's your competition.
Ann, you have to address it due to some market.
So it's when said yes we can start with SMB market.
It has a great potential is a big market you can learn on it so we know what's the market.
We know what's the service.
Actually, the first thing now that we learn that well, SMB market is not so big for the countries in Eastern Europe or Eastern media.
So you have actually to scale your cloud but down not up but down.
And that's first major topic.
You have to think about.
The second thing is something you can actually address through some marketing study, either doing it yourself or using some agency is what you have to provide to end customer.
So going.
Look into what we can provide, what we have learned from our experience.

Is first of all you will start with some initial market segment, but you want to remain flexible for the future because once you went in invest in one cloud solution, probably we won't be able to invest in another one.
The problem with that approach is actually that.
Each market segments requires a bit different services, so they may look alike, but at the end it's not the same.
For instance, if you are providing cloud services to enterprises, you will probably be asked for something like a single sign-on between their own domain and your cloud domain.
So you are talking about some sort of hybrid cloud services, and this is basically something that's very strange request if you're talking to SMBs or.
Consumers.
So first of all we have to deploy something that will.
Be able to cover all of that.
Now second thing is one thing is to deploy a service an obviously we cannot be as cheap as Amazon, so we have to provide something else.
Now, if you are looking at enterprises or companies, they do have requests or do they?
They do have needs that are growing through the time, so probably the local PC is not good enough.
So they added Internet on it.
So right now they have PC and Internet.
Probably that's also not enough or it won't be enough in few years from now on.
So you can address this rising needs to your cloud and end.
Add something extra to justify bigger price.
But you get another problem that consumer requirements are something much more different there arising as at much higher rifts.
Gray Dan.
If you look now at all the smartphones at Apple's iPods, tablets, androids.
You actually get into a very big gap between enterprise needs and consumer needs.
Now, once you're talking about cloud, it's really hard to.
To say to somebody, no, this is just for enterprises.
It's not the cloud you are getting from Amazon and Apple.
No, no, no.
This is just for enterprises, so this doesn't go so.
Basically you have to provide everything.
The problem is following with.
With enterprise benefit you adjust.
Addressing very small, very small.
Part of that gap and basically addressing that with appropriate security with flexible open platform.
That's something that's working on.

Perhaps every device you have in your office that's working with all the applications you have in your office, but the problem is with this bigger gap, and basically that's where you have to provide additional features and benefits to have a happy customer that will pay a bit more.
So yes, you have to provide.
High definition video.
Yes, you have to provide flash right direction or flash support.
Yes you have have to provide support for tablets support for Android support for iOS and perhaps tomorrow.
Chrome OS will be more popular than Android or perhaps BlackBerry tablet will come and will be more popular than its Android.
So you basically have to accommodate all the platforms you have and give this specific.
Specific user benefits now.
One of the benefits benefits of course is what we already heard and it's self service portals.
So users want a very simple service.
They want it easy to use and they want it activate it right away.
I want to click it and I want to have it.
No.
Going a bit more technical, when you start deploying a service, you basically get a problem of economies of scale.
Largest provider of virtual private servers in Hungary, for example, has less than 1000 virtual servers.
Now, compared to 150,000 new servers each day on Amazon, while you get the gap and the problem you have with business case.
So you have to do something that's better.
You probably won't get to Amazon scale, but you have to do as best as you can.

You have to provide all the different services and be flexible for all those market segments you you seen before an you have to provide all the enterprise and customer benefits so the service can be solved.
So in that sense, what we're doing.
We're basically putting a common infrastructure block in place.
Now I'm not talking about hardware, hardware is beneath this.
So we are just spending once for the common infrastructure and then on top of that.
Then we are adding different cloud services.
In a way or in timescale, you want to add it so.
One platform, one cloud, that can provide different services.
Basically something that you get from Swiss Army knife.
It gets all those different things.
You can put it out and then took it away as you need it.
So an on the way you don't want to pay very much for that.
Yes you will pay a premium.
It's not the cheapest knife, but at the end it doesn't cost too much.
And on top of that to provide something that's user friendly, we're using a set of self-service portals.
An set of provisioning procedures so that everything gets done automatically.
Now if I go to a concrete business case, the first cloud platform that we have, diploid was in creation Telecom or her Hrvatska telecom.
And specifically we have diploid virtual desktops.
Now one thing I have mentioned we have deployed desktop that's basically the same overall the platform.
So you get something like a follow me desktop.
Whatever you're doing you get Windows 7 and that Windows 7 gets up and running or your iPad on your Android device on your smartphone whatever.
Basically device you need, so we're not limited to any location either physically are there.
From the device perspective you can use it wherever you are.
End of top of that, we are actually adding self-service portals, so they have those that cloud like ease of management and provisioning processes that are done automatically.
Do we basically a bit more precise with cloud computer you get some kind of storage space.
You get all the different things that you should get, like antivirus protection.
You get integrated backup and restore, which is also served serviced through portals through the desktop for user himself.
So there is no need to call a customer care and you get set of applications.
Let's say that a standard to PC computer.
On top of that, you get self-service portals with integrated application store.
So all those applications you might have, you want to offer a user come from a web based application store.
You click it and they get installed on the on the desktop.
So it it is a cloud experience that you would.
That you would that you would get from any other provider in the world.
Just to give you an idea.
Something like this?
So getting a cloud computer with the application store and self-service portal right now in Croatia costs around 15 euros per month.
Now.
I wouldn't like to talk about this too much.
It's already late and we are running late through through the schedule.
You can see the service either on the web or you can see it.
Also, some case studies ANAN video and user cases on our on Columbus website so you can check the details of the service.
But the bottom line is.
What you have to do?
To provide some.
Which service in eastern India what you have to do and what are those specifics that are different than Amazon to deployer successful service?
Now.
From our experience we now have.
Fort A telecom operator contract ING with US Cloud service and we're speaking, speaking with numerous numerous others.
Basically all in this Eastern EMEA region.
What we saw that there are few things that we have to work on and at a very important in essence they are typical cloud.
I would say request in terms of flexibility and price but they are a bit different in this local.
Region.
So user experience is still very important.
The TCO or business case has to be reasonable, has to hold water becausw the number of users is not so great as as Amazon and you still want to make money.
You have to provide all different services to address different market segments and you have to provide it from one cloud.
You basically you cannot be profitable if you invest in more than one cloud.
And something that basically Noel Cloud provider will tell you is that basically have to provide something that we could call standardized customizations.
So going into from SMB to SMS to enterprises, everybody will have some different and specific requirements.
And basically, if you don't address those, you don't get a customer.
And this is basically what you're doing differently than Amazon.
This is why you can get a local customer.
But of course you have to do it in some some way that all those changes.
All those customizations remain basically manageable.
And of course they don't.
They cannot cost too much.

On the sales and marketing side now the thing that we saw the most is that basically there is a lot of need and lots of efforts needed to address internal processes, anneline internal processes and sales force inside telecom to sell IT services.
Selling it or cloud services is a bit different than selling SIM cards or selling a DS lines.
And typically you have to work with sales, an internal stuff.
To get everything aligned so you have a successful selling.
On other side your offer dollar then customer has to be a bit tweaked so you cannot just offer it as a service that's available on the website.
Go there with your credit card and start it.

That way you cannot compete with Amazon and likes, so you either bundling that service in something like GNU outsourcing types or in something like providing a complete workplace for your own customer.
That's very flexible in terms of size, so especially on, let's say, Adriatic Sea during summer times, you need like 2030% more workforce than during winter months, so you can do this with cloud.
Or on the other side, through your application through basically a marketplace or application store, you can build a.
Up basically UN used or new application store with all the applications.
All these services you offering but also with applications and services from any other local software developer or local cloud providers.
So basically in essence you are aggregating content from the region.

And of course at the end, basically there are niches that are more specific or more adaptable to cloud offerings like school systems or health care systems where there is bigger chance on offering a cloud solution with less customizations, perhaps with then to other customers.
So with that, if you have any questions, I'm at your.
Disposal about thank you very much for your attention.
